Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 07:46PM tomatojuice wrote: I am 6 months post op. Two months ago I developed pain and cording in my arm. I had 18 nodes removed. Are you seeing a physical therapist for your arm. Might be a good idea to get in touch with a therapist, because of the swelling. Also  you should find a LANA certified therapist, because having 19 nodes removed means you are at risk of developing lymphadema. Hopefully that is not the case, but to be on the safe side, you should have your arm checked. Also there are exercises(stretches) that you should be doing post-op. A LE therapist can advise you about certain exercises, and also simple life long protective measures to help prevent swelling or infection.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 10:05PM tomatojuice wrote: I'm doing TCH. It's taxotere, carboplatin and herceptin every 3 weeks. My third is on June 4th. The first and second treatment were pretty much the same for me. I also get a nuelasta shot  the day after the chemo. For me I have felt pretty much okay, til about the third day-then I got a little emotional, and felt kinda wired. I think the steroids made me feel that way. Also had a metal taste that lasted for a couple of days.I did not have any nausea. They put zofran in the I.V. to prevent this. My Onc also gave me a script for phenergan, but fortunately I have not had to use it. Around day 10 I had a mild case of diarrhea in the mornings for a couple of days. By around day 12 I usually feel great. The third week is great. Its like a little vacation before the next treatment. All in all Its way better than I expected. So I'm hoping the next 4 treatments is more of the same. Because it is just so doable. I have also been able to carry on as usual throughout the first two treatments -shopping, walking around the city. Doing my part time job. Even exercising-walk eorobics, and a bit on the treadmill. I know evryones different, but I think with the antiemetics and the steroids that chemo se's are not as bad as they were years ago. Hopefully, and probably it will be okay for you to.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 08:25AM tomatojuice wrote: Hi Binney and everyone....Turns out that the red looking rash on my stomach, isn't lymphadema after all. I have had it for over a year, and numerous doctors have looked at it(saying they know not what it is). But I have been persistent. It has been treated with Keflex twice in the past year and 1/2. Still there. So I decided to go back to my dermatologist. I go to a clioinic, so the initial Dr. that checked it out, gave the same diagnosis. But he then brought in his superior to have a look. A very old Asian Dr. (dermatologist- oncologist). He examined me and had no trouble finding what it was. He said I have a Lipoma(a fatty tissur tumor, thats usually benign). He felt it, and had the other doctor feel it. I am a little more freaked out. Usually doesn't mean never. I have been watching the rt. side of my stomach grow bigger than the left for a year now. The last thing the doctor told me is it is going to get bigger. Somehow I keep thinking it has something to do with my surgery, because it sits right below where my breat was removed. I am seeing my oncologist this friday. I want to have an MRI. To find out its size, how big it will get, can I have it removed, and is there any possibility of it being cancer. I have read online where swollen lymph nodes were mistaken for Lipomas and where other types of tumors were also mistaken by just touch. Well thanks everyone for your feedback, on everything.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 02:03AM tomatojuice wrote: I had a right masectomy. I found bathing and showering right after surgery difficult, mostly because of the axillary disection. I couldn't stand to touch under my arm at all, let alone with a face rag. I bought a bath and shower gel. There are many different brands to be found in most drug stores. But I like Avalon Organics mostly found in health food stores. It says right on the bottle gentle cleansing, and that it truely is. It lathers up real nice-you don't need a cloth. Comes in many different scents-I like the rosemary. Its so refreshing-even still 3 months post op -its the only soap I can stand under my arm.

Posts.Content: tomatojuice wrote: Was diagnosed with infection in my arm 10 days ago. Given keflex 500mg 2xday. Had swelling in hand throughout this time. I have another two days of keflex left. My doctor looked at the arm two days ago. She said she believes the infection is gone. I do have very pinkish skin to begin with, but I still see the infection on my arm. Yes it has faded, but it is still there. I am scheduled to have a herceptin treatment this wed.-am also concerned about being on antibiotica and getting hercptin. My doctor is has not finished her fellowship yet-I am not sure if she really knows what she is looking at. Also I had a problem getting in to see her on friday(she didn't return my call). Had a total meltdown with her sec, and a partial meltdown with her-when I did see her. I don't know why she is saying the infection is gone. I still see it.Very worried. Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 03:03PM - edited May 16, 2008 03:04PM by tomatojuice Hi I had a right masectomy. I am 58, divorced, very happily single, not looking at all.When I told the surgeon that I wanted a bilateral, she discouraged me,and urged me to see a plastic surgeon about reconstruction. She mentioned something about a big scar across my chest. So I proceeded to the plastic surgeon.From the minute he touched me and explained the possibilities-I knew immediately that I wanted none of it. I wanted to run out of his office. He was immensely insensitive, also. He said, step into my lab, and took a picture of me naked. Then he literally grabbed and pinched my stomach, and said I had enough fat for a diep, or something. I had to remind him that it was me he was pinching. The whole experience is one I definately want to forget.But it wasn't just his manner that made me decide against reconstruction. I am sure there are good plastic surgeons around. I just didn't want the extra pain, or possible se's. I didn't relish the idea of being asymetrical.But now it doesn't bother me at all. I have been fitted for a lightweight prothesis.But for some reason I prefer the little puff that the breast cancer society gave me in the hospital. I really like it, it feels like a soft little cushion to lean on, and looks great.Sometimes I do get nervous though about still having my other breast, so maybe somewhere down the road I will have another masectomy.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 09:12AM - edited Sep 1, 2008 09:47AM by tomatojuice Oh Binney how so very kind of you to think of me at this big event for LE. I am grateful to you, as I have noticed my stress levels have definately increased due to the infection. I still have redness, no new spread. ITs just that it all seems very strange to me, because the redness emanates from the crux of my elbow, where the cords are very visible. Also it hurts to the touch in this area. My LE therapist suggested that I resume my stretching exercises and also to keep my arm raised on the pillows. I do the exercise to the point of resitance-but I keep somehow thinking(Is this maybe making things worse?). The LE therapist never did teach me the massage. I saw her twice. And I do not have a sleeve and glove yet. I went to be fitted, but they would not fit me while I had the infection. Then they gave me a lenghthy letter for my insurance, which I am waiting for my doctor to do for me. On Tuesday I have some phone calls to make-doctor & LE therapist.I do not have fever or warmth. All of this is happening when I am about to begin radiation treatment. Even though I have already done simulation, my team of doctors decided to get together to decide if I need it or not. There consensis was that I did, because I have an extranodal extension. Waiting for them to call me, I thought my head would explode. Thankfully though they did call on Friday before this long weeken. And I was able to relax some.I work part time(2-3days wk).I can't imagine what this like for women with children, and full time jobs, or who have to travel far to their hospitals. I woke up this morning feeling so emotionally drained, thinking that I need to do something to counter it. What that is I don't know. Just can't wait to be finished .
